row.AboutMe:
Computer Vision Master's degree from Czech Technical University in Prague.

In software development since 2001.

I love programming and mathematics.

I try to answer your questions to the best of my ability, so I can provide you a nice experience on StackExchange. I also edit questions with due diligence as I believe a well crafted question attracts sincere quality answers.

Feel free to ask me to answer/edit your question! :)

An Application Engineer

SOreadytohelp

I'm interested in PHP in general, and especially in Symfony.

Want to know the true values of your Stack Exchange badges? Go on TrueBadges (StackApps question) and register.

Editing a question to change links to inline images

Pending questions:

  • StackApps:

  • Getting global information (Stack Exchange) about a list of users

  • Meta Stack Exchange (Android app):

  • https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/230134/site-selection-drop-down-offer-already-pinned-sites-to-be-pinned

  • https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/230131/how-to-get-back-to-a-site-when-viewing-one-of-its-questions

Ready-to-use comments:

  • Welcome on Stack Overflow, please provide the code with the error, this website is about helping other people, not writing code for them.
  • Please provide a [mcve].
  • Hi @user12345 if this or any answer has solved your question please consider [accepting it](https://meta.stackexchange.com/a/5235/237701) by clicking the check-mark. This indicates to the wider community that you've found a solution and gives some reputation to both the answerer and yourself. There is no obligation to do this. (source)
World traveler and aeronautical engineer.

Hello! I'm Sudipta.

Busy building Robots..

Ten. Million. Questions. #SOreadytohelp

Here's a shout-out to the hero of Stack Exchange! You're the best!

I like Go, as a statically typed C-style-OOP systems programming language, but it doesn't have generics, and doesn't encourage functional practices. D encourages functional programming, proper OOP and fixes the problems of C and Go while being a better C++, and more productive / less dumb than Java.

While I love Python, it feels too mundane; for everyday tasks I prefer Racket and Factor.

Confused college student. I like water, sci-fi novels, airplanes, and sometimes computers. The picture is a speeding penguin.

Airline brat and minor avgeek. I want to work for the airlines someday, though I'm not sure how.

Started learning Objective-C in mid-2012 then moved to Swift when it was released in 2014.

Currently a student studying Computer Programming. I have been into iOS development as of late, and hope to get into the iOS development field once I finish my studies.
How about now?
I like to break stuff to figure out how things work!

Computer Vision Master's degree from Czech Technical University in Prague.

In software development since 2001.

I love programming and mathematics.
Part time aviation enthusiast.

Kiwi, 9 years in London, 1 in Barcelona, just moved to Dubai. Most of my time in PHP, being a tech lead and project manager, and in the evenings learning Python. Always have personal projects on the go.

[ Software Engineer ] [ Moderator ] [ Volunteer ] [ Gamer ] [ Father ] [ He/Him ]

Hello, my name is Ryan, I'm an Elected Moderator on Arqade, the video gaming Stack Exchange site.

I'm a full-stack Software Engineer with years of experience in Web and App development. My current tech stack consists primarily of HTML5/JS (React, Typescript), as well as AWS Microservices, Postgres, and a bit of C#. Over the years I've worked with a multitude of technologies: ASP.NET, Android/iOS development, Xbox One and Windows 10 Apps (Both XAML and HTML based ones), Java and so on.

I also volunteer in Environment & Sustainability groups in my local area (if you're reading this and into that sort of stuff, you should join the Sustainable Living SE!).

I enjoy many video, board and card games, as well as D&D as both DM and player. I'm currently playing in a Star Wars 5e campaign, as a naive Droid Engineer: TA-1! Check it out here: Star Wars D&D.

Find me on:

  • YouTube - A Pinch of Salt (Group channel) - game-play and gaming/tech podcasts with friends
  • YouTube - RobotnikPlays - (Personal channel) - game-play, achievements, tricks and techniques, time trials, and commentary on gaming in general.
  • Steam - My primary gaming platform
  • Discord - A Pinch of Salt - Video gaming, D&D, tech and lots more.

BY DAY: I navigate the sea of requirements and safety hazards between the gargantuan regulators and evil genius test engineers. I can untangle instrumentation channels as well as federal, state and local electrical regulations better than anybody. And these days, I watch out for the risk. In all seriousness, I manage a growing electrical safety and regulatory compliance program in a division of lab testing.

BY NIGHT: Part ring-master, part short-order cook for three superheroes... aka MOMMY!!

FOR FUN: I power-up at strategic locations near and far, acquire supplies, uptake caffeine, and capture and sustain knowledge. I'll let you deduce this one.
Currently a PhD research fellow in maths and CS at Høgskulen på Vestlandet. In the past I have worked as a musician, as a programmer on magnetohydrodynamics number-crunchers, and studied geophysics.

Long time hobby coder since the 80s and hacking games on my Acorn Atom or building SBC from plans in Elektor magazine. Technically I have a degree in Electronics but since I got it in the 80s but since technology has advanced so much it is little more than a pretty certificate in a frame that hides a section of my bad plastering. Code mostly in Java, VB, VBA, some C and a little Forth for fun. I spend a lot of work time writing data mining and text manipulation code in VB to automate long, boring and repetitive tasks.

Typical engineer, I will spent days working on a problem to save me 10 minutes effort.

I fly gliders, mountain bike and love being in the woods with a hammock, a fire and a coffee.

Senior Undergraduate Biology Major with 3 Years of Bioinformatics/Computational Biology Research. Focusing on Machine Learning, Genetic Algorithms, and other approaches for modeling transcriptional regulatory networks.
rat of stan by any other name
Python programmer, Django core developer, team member at Divio.

David the expat sez: "Stack Exchange Rocks!" so, let Stack Exchange be Stack Exchange.

My goal is to spend less time in my "...snow white cube containing only the bare necessities, a computer, and a large library of treatises, maps, and precise scale models*."

I am an experienced developer specialising in Azure based .Net web applications. I have recently been working with Angular 6, ReactJs, .Net Core, Azure Functions and Cosmos Db. I aim to develop maintainable, reliable, tested solutions, based on SOLID principles, which closely match business needs.
A Physicist interested in way too many things.
Air Traffic Controller
I hacked NASA with a toaster
Founder Boostport.

I'm a (Python mostly) developer from CA, looking to learn, make connections & share what I know. Interests: nature, linux, martial arts, medicine, natural language processing, better mobile ux, web development, cross-platform desktop development, virtualization technology, data visualization, etc.

Whether it be Object Oriented, Event Driven, or Functional programming, it's great to do!

I'm a professional software developer who does mostly web development (with some other random tidbits here and there) during my day job.

I also have experience with a variety of languages and frameworks and am always game to learn a new one.
I don't know what to say-I simply love the Tupolev Tu-144.

Research assistant, student of computer science, former freelancer, computer & space exploration nerd.

I have experience in theoretical computer science and maths, as well as more practical experience in object oriented programming, functional programming, relational database design and many web technologies, including html5, xml, json, yaml and other DSLs, sql (mostly mysql, mssql and hsql), javascript and asp.net-core.

I'm currently researching purpose-specific languages and their applications in various domains to make programming easier for domain-experts, according to the motto "Easy for them, hard for us".

I prefer working with strongly-typed programming languages and primarily work with Java and C#. I am actively following JDK development and the upcoming features, as well as how to integrate them into applications. Programming languages I have used professionally include:

  • java (including Java 8, 11 and newer)
  • php (up until 7.1)
  • c#

I am interested in studying and following established standards as well as creating new, unique and innovative solutions for business problems, focusing on ease-of-use, maintainability, extensibility and creating value for the customer. As such, I am also active on Software Engineering.SE.

I am an avid space exploration fan and also active on Space SE.

IT & media nut in Melbourne, Australia.
DevOps engineer at Kablamo.
Contact me via Twitter.

I'm a bit of a philomath with wide interests and you'll probably see me commenting, questioning, answering - or just quietly browsing and voting - right across the StackExchange network.

My day job primarily involves AWS, DevOps, security, automation and Linux. But depending on what phase I'm going through you might find I'm also in to: server management, Node.js, Python, Go, programming in general, the web, travel, software, FLOSS software, web apps, finance, politics, coffee, Christianity and the Bible, learning languages, cooking, IT in general, workplace culture, psychology, Ubuntu, IoT, movies, getting outdoors, being productive, cycling, planes and trains, doing stuff around the house, chess, living sustainably, genealogy, hacking life, listening to music, playing board games, or law. Not all at the same time, mind you.

To make life easier for you, any original code that I post in my responses is available under CC0. Attribution is always nice when possible, but you are not legally required to do so.

Former pictures: Dakota puddles (prairie potholes), 2012-01-30; Yellowstone River icicles, 12 Dec 2011; Black-and-white ducks on YR, ca 6 Jan 2012; Eagle in eastwind snow, on south bank of YR, 15 Jan 2012; Sunlight & shadows on riverbottom, 5 Feb 2012; Duck in park puddle, June 2011; Trumpeter swan pair on YR, 13 Feb 2012; American Avocet on YR, 10 May 2012; Pelicans flying above YR, 24 June 2012, and pelican in YR, 16 May 2012; Rainbow above Livingston Peak, 23 July 2012; Rose/squirrel, 21 Nov 2012; old Bangalore station, Dec 2004; Bighorn sheep, Zion, 8 Nov 2013

Industry experience in power electronics since 2000 at two different companies in the Greater Toronto area. Roles include: production technician, sustaining engineering, product development (electrical and embedded) and test engineering. Currently a senior test engineering specialist focusing on automatic test development for high-density PMBus AC/DC and DC/DC power supplies.

  • Certified Engineering Technologist [Ontario Association of Certified Engineering Technicians and Technologists]
  • Certified LabVIEW Developer [National Instruments]
  • Master Certificate in Project Management [Atocrates, Inc. and Durham College]
  • Computer Programming - Engineering certificate [Ryerson University - The Chang School]

row.DisplayName: X-27 is done with the network
row.AboutMe: SE now has almost no resemblance to the SE I contributed to.
Oxford-based software engineer, amateur pilot, and singer. He/him or they/them.

I work writing models and simulations for various types of physical systems. Mainly using Fortran for the computational work, and JavaScript (along with HTML and CSS) for user interfaces and scripting. I also use a smattering of C++, Python, and the operating system scripting languages.

I have an interest in ode solvers, filtering, minimization routines, boundary value problems, and other numerical methods in the interest of simulation and answering scientific computing problems.

Fortran is a vastly underrated language, and just needs a few pieces of infrastructure to be considered fully modernized

All day, and all of the night!

Don't try to sell me those stamps! There is no value printed on them!

When she returned to her bomb-struck house, my granny sighed: "Shhhit... I just cleaned the stairs"

I like Nature and it makes me sad to see Her disappear.

Hey! don't drink from that bottle! It contains a poisonous drink...costs 60 bucks...

I like the sciences and every kind of art, including non-western art which has much more meaning. It represents a world-view, just as the sciences do, so you can call the sciences an art. This is made clear by Paul Feyerabend in his little book "Wissenschaft als Kunst".

I like Paul Feyerabend. As another philosopher of the sciences once said:

I know no other person who has written one book ("Against Method") in three different editions with different content.

His most cited and most misinterpreted one-liner: "Anything goes".

People like Richard Dawkins have written many books, with many different covers. But with the same content (and gospel Truth), over and over again.

I'm particularly interested in physics, which strangely enough in the Netherlands is called "Natuurkunde"="knowledge of Nature", while everywhere else it's called something like it's called in English. But over here you can call it "fysica" too. Just so, mathematics is called "wiskunde"="knowledge of erasing". And just like "fysica" and "wiskunde" in Dutch there is the strange word "magnetron" which stands for "microwave oven".

I like every field. From the small(est) to the big(est). From classical to modern. I'm very interested in, even a fan, of the Rishon Model.

I think everybody should see this tear-jerking documentary. Or this one. Or this beautiful movie. Or this one.

Why so much tax money is spent on the biggest constructions to find the smallest?

Longfellow:

If thou art worn and hard beset
By troubles that thou wouldst forget
If thou wouldst read a lesson that would keep
Thy heart from fainting and thy soul from sleep

Go to the woods and hills
No tears
Can dim the sweet look
That Nature wears

I know that the western train should slow down instead of racing up, productivity shrink instead of inflating, energy be clean instead of smelly and portable instead of static, and products be renewable instead of disposable if we want Nature to survive. If we don't want birds to fall from the sky, seas to devour, superstorms to rage, sweet water to taste bitter, unworldly screaming to be heard from within, the last trees to burn.
I am a Dutch amateur mathematician currently interested in probability, combinatorics, number theory, calculus, algebra, geometry, set theory, computability theory, graph theory and group theory.

Volunteering in academia is immoral and wrong.

My pronouns are he/him, but they/them is fine too.

My interests are in linguistics and psych. PhD student.

Civil engg Graduate, M. SC in Structural Engg, CEng, M.I. STruct.E,Chartered Structural Engineer, Member of the Institution of Structural Engineers, London, Self employed as director of Baseraft Limited, UK(1974-1988), currently director of Baseraft Consultants Pvt Ltd, India. Mainly worked on problems involving design for blast & impact loads. Current interest runway safety areas (RSA)(FAA requirements) and emergency landings before or after reaching critical point V-1 during take-off.
MSci in Physics. MSc in Physics of Opto-Electronic Devices. Studied for but did not complete PhD in Ultra-short Pulsed Lasers.

I'll tell you what I am not: I am not in IT, I am not a native English speaker, I am not a creature of the night. But I started dabbling in C and sh (no Bash yet back then) in the early 80s as I was doing my Ph.D. (but mostly playing rogue, 5 times a total winner, it's in my CV). I remember coming from IBM's CMS and looking in awe at all the code free for anyone to see and study. I have been hooked on *Nix ever since.

I have now retired from full time work. I was working in London UK providing consultancy on software testing using Visual Studio and associated Microsoft tools. My background as a developer allows me to exploit Microsoft's .Net and C# for some of the interesting challenges with automating testing. I have been developing software for many years including a lot of real-time software written in C and several other programming languages.
Professor at Eastern Kentucky University, teach classes including Java, Android Programming, Operating Systems and Networking.

I took Java in high school as an advance placement class and took some Java classes in College. Now I'm working at a place that involves MATLAB. I enjoy programming personal things on my free time like Arduino.
Air Traffic Controller, flight simulator enthusiast, former glider pilot.

Senior at Caltech, BS '23 (Computer Science). Ex-professional web developer.

Loves Haskell (and functional programming in general) and, recently, Coq.
